div.head: SCENE I
div.stage: Athens. A hall in Timon's house.

Enter Poet, Painter, Jeweller, Merchant, and others,
at several doors.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Good day, sir.

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: I am glad you're well.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l:
I have not seen you long: how goes
the world?

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: It wears, sir, as it grows.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Ay, that's well known:
But what particular rarity? what strange,
Which manifold record not matches? See,
Magic of bounty! all these spirits thy power

Hath conjured to attend.
I know the merchant.

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: I know them both; th' other's a jeweller.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O, 'tis a worthy lord.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Nay, that's most fix'd.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: A most incomparable man, breathed, as it were,
To an untirable and continuate goodness:
He passes.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: I have a jewel here--

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O, pray, let's see't: for the Lord Timon, sir?

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: If he will touch the estimate: but, for that--

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: 'When we for recompense have praised the vile,
It stains the glory in that happy verse
Which aptly sings the good.'

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: 'Tis a good form. [Looking at the jewel.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: And rich: here is a water, look ye.

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: You are rapt, sir, in some work, some dedication
To the great lord.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: A thing slipp'd idly from me.
Our poesy is as a gum, which oozes
From whence 'tis nourish'd: the fire i' the flint
Shows not till it be struck; our gentle flame
Provokes itself and like the current flies
Each bound it chafes. What have you there?

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: A picture, sir. When comes your book forth?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Upon the heels of my presentment, sir.
Let's see your piece.

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: 'Tis a good piece.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: So 'tis: this comes off well and excellent.

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: Indifferent.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Admirable: how this grace
Speaks his own standing! what a mental power
This eye shoots forth! how big imagination
Moves in this lip to the dumbness of the gesture
One might interpret.

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: It is a pretty mocking of the life.
Here is a touch; is't good?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: I will say of it,
It tutors nature: artificial strife

Lives in these touches, livelier than life.
Enter certain Senators, and pass over.

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: How this lord is follow'd!

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: The senators of Athens: happy man!

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: Look, more!

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: You see this confluence, this great flood of visitors.
I have, in this rough work, shaped out a man,
Whom this beneath world doth embrace and hug
With amplest entertainment: my free drift
Halts not particularly, but moves itself
In a wide sea of wax: no levell'd malice
Infects one comma in the course I hold;
But flies an eagle flight, bold and forth on,
Leaving no tract behind.

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: How shall I understand you?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: I will unbolt to you.
You see how all conditions, how all minds,
As well of glib and slippery creatures as
Of grave and austere quality, tender down
Their services to Lord Timon: his large fortune
Upon his good and gracious nature hanging
Subdues and properties to his love and tendance
All sorts of hearts; yea, from the glass-faced flatterer
To Apemantus, that few things loves better
Than to abhor himself: even he drops down
The knee before him and returns in peace
Most rich in Timon's nod.

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: I saw them speak together.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Sir, I have upon a high and pleasant hill

Feign'd Fortune to be throned:
the base o' the mount
Is rank'd with all deserts, all kind of natures,
That labour on the bosom of this sphere
To propagate their states: amongst them all,
Whose eyes are on this sovereign lady fix'd,
One do I personate of Lord Timon's frame,
Whom fortune with her ivory hand wafts to her;
Whose present grace to present slaves and servants
Translates his rivals.

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: 'Tis conceived to scope.
This throne, this Fortune, and this hill, methinks,
With one man beckon'd from the rest below,
Bowing his head against the steepy mount
To climb his happiness, would be well express'd
In our condition.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: Nay, sir, but hear me on.
All those which were his fellows but of late,
Some better than his value, on the moment
Follow his strides, his lobbies fill with tendance,
Rain sacrificial whispering in his ear,
Make sacred even his stirrup, and through him
Drink the free air.

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: Ay, marry, what of these?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: When Fortune in her shift and change of mood
Spurns down her late beloved, all his dependants
Which labour'd after him to the mountain's top
Even on their knees and hands, let him slip down,
Not one accompanying his declining foot.

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: 'Tis common:
A thousand moral paintings I can show
That shall demonstrate these quick blows of Fortune's
More pregnantly than words. Yet you do well
To show Lord Timon that mean eyes have seen

The foot above the head.
Trumpets sound.
Enter LORD TIMON, addressing himself courteously
to every suitor;
a Messenger from VENTIDIUS talking with
him: LUCILIUS and other servants following.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Imprison'd is he, say you?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Ay, my good lord: five talents is his debt,
His means most short, his creditors most strait:
Your honourable letter he desires
To those have shut him up; which failing,
Periods his comfort.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Noble Ventidius! Well;
I am not of that feather to shake off
My friend when he must need me. I do know him
A gentleman that well deserves a help:
Which he shall have: I'll pay the debt, and free him.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Your lordship ever binds him.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Commend me to him: I will send his ransom;
And being enfranchised, bid him come to me.
'Tis not enough to help the feeble up,
But to support him after. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l:
All happiness to your honour! [Exit.
Enter an old Athenian.

sp.speaker: Old Ath.
sp.l: Lord Timon, hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Freely, good father.

sp.speaker: Old Ath.
sp.l: Thou hast a servant named Lucilius.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I have so: what of him?

sp.speaker: Old Ath.
sp.l: Most noble Timon, call the man before thee.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Attends he here, or no? Lucilius!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Here, at your lordship's service.

sp.speaker: Old Ath.
sp.l: This fellow here, Lord Timon, this thy creature,
By night frequents my house. I am a man
That from my first have been inclined to thrift;
And my estate deserves an heir more raised
Than one which holds a trencher.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Well; what further?

sp.speaker: Old Ath.
sp.l: One only daughter have I, no kin else,
On whom I may confer what I have got:
The maid is fair, o' the youngest for a bride,
And I have bred her at my dearest cost
In qualities of the best. This man of thine
Attempts her love: I prithee, noble lord,
Join with me to forbid him her resort;
Myself have spoke in vain.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: The man is honest.

sp.speaker: Old Ath.
sp.l: Therefore he will be, Timon:
His honesty rewards him in itself;
It must not bear my daughter.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Does she love him?

sp.speaker: Old Ath.
sp.l: She is young and apt:
Our own precedent passions do instruct us
What levity's in youth.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Love you the maid?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Ay, my good lord, and she accepts of it.

sp.speaker: Old Ath.
sp.l: If in her marriage my consent be missing,
I call the gods to witness, I will choose
Mine heir from forth the beggars of the world,
And dispossess her all.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: How shall she be endow'd,
If she be mated with an equal husband?

sp.speaker: Old Ath.
sp.l: Three talents on the present; in future, all.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l:
This gentleman of mine
hath served me long:
To build his fortune I will strain a little,
For 'tis a bond in men. Give him thy daughter:
What you bestow, in him I'll counterpoise,
And make him weigh with her.

sp.speaker: Old Ath.
sp.l: Most noble lord,
Pawn me to this your honour, she is his.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l:
My hand to thee;
mine honour on my promise.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Humbly I thank your lordship: never may
That state or fortune fall into my keeping,
Which is not owed to you! Exeunt Lucilius and Old Athenian.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l:
Vouchsafe my labour,
and long live your lordship!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I thank you; you shall hear from me anon:
Go not away. What have you there, my friend ?

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: A piece of painting, which I do beseech
Your lordship to accept.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Painting is welcome.
The painting is almost the natural man;
For since dishonour traffics with man's nature,
He is but outside: these pencill'd figures are
Even such as they give out. I like your work;
And you shall find I like it: wait attendance
Till you hear further from me.

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: The gods preserve ye!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Well fare you, gentleman: give me your hand:
We must needs dine together. Sir, your jewel
Hath suffer'd under praise.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: What, my lord! dispraise?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: A mere satiety of commendations.
If I should pay you for't as 'tis extoll'd,
It would unclew me quite.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: My lord, 'tis rated
As those which sell would give: but you well know,
Things of like value differing in the owners
Are prized by their masters: believe't, dear lord,
You mend the jewel by the wearing it.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Well mock'd.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No, my good lord; he speaks the common tongue,
Which all men speak with him.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Look, who comes here: will you be chid? Enter APEMANTUS.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: We'll bear, with your lordship.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: He'll spare none.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l:
Good morrow to thee,
gentle Apemantus!

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.l: Till I be gentle, stay thou for thy good morrow;
When thou art Timon's dog, and these knaves honest.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l:
Why dost thou call them knaves? thou know'st
them not.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.l: Are they not Athenians?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.l: Then I repent not.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: You know me, Apemantus?

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.l: Thou know'st I do: I call'd thee by thy name.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Thou art proud, Apemantus.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
Of nothing so much as that I am
not like Timon.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Whither art going?

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
To knock out an honest Athenian's
brains.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: That's a deed thou'lt die for.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
Right, if doing nothing be death by
the law.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: How likest thou this picture, Apemantus?

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p: The best, for the innocence.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Wrought he not well that painted it?

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
He wrought better that made the
painter; and
yet he's but a filthy piece of
work.

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.p: You're a dog.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
Thy mother's of my generation:
what's she, if I
be a dog?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Wilt dine with me, Apemantus?

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p: No; I eat not lords.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
An thou shouldst, thou'ldst anger
ladies.

sp.speaker: Apem.
Tim.
sp.p: That's a lascivious apprehension.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
So thou apprehendest it:
take it for
thy labour.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: How dost thou like this jewel, Apemantus ?

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
Not so well as plain-dealing, which
will not cost
a man a doit.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: What dost thou think 'tis worth?

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
Not worth my thinking.
How now,
poet!

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: How now, philosopher!

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p: Thou liest.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Art not one?

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Then I lie not.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p: Art not a poet?

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
Then thou liest:
look in thy last
work, where thou hast feigned him a
worthy
fellow.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: That's not feigned; he is so.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
Yes, he is worthy of thee, and to
pay thee for thy
labour: he that loves to be
flattered is worthy o' the flatterer.
Heavens,
that I were a lord!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: What wouldst do then, Apemantus?

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
E'en as Apemantus does now; hate
a lord with
my heart.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: What, thyself?

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p: Ay.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
That I had no angry wit to be a
lord.
Art not thou a merchant?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Ay, Apemantus.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
Traffic confound thee, if the gods
will not!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: If traffic do it, the gods do it.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
Traffic's thy god; and thy god confound
thee!
Trumpet sounds. Enter a Messenger.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: What trumpet's that?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: 'Tis Alcibiades, and some twenty horse,
All of companionship.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Pray, entertain them; give them guide to us. [Exeunt some Attendants.
You must needs dine with me: go not you hence
Till I have thank'd you: when dinner's done,

Show me this piece. I am joyful of your sights.
Enter ALCIBIADES, with the rest.
Most welcome, sir!

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.l: So, so, there!

Aches contract and starve your
supple joints!

That there should be small love 'mongst
these sweet knaves,

And all this courtesy! The strain of
man's bred out
Into baboon and monkey.

sp.speaker: Alcib.
sp.l: Sir, you have saved my longing, and I feed
Most hungerly on your sight.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Right welcome, sir!
Ere we depart, we 'll share a bounteous time

In different pleasures.
Pray you, let us in. [Exeunt all except Apemantus.
Enter two Lords.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p: What time o' day is't, Apemantus ?

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p: Time to be honest.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p: That time serves still.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p: The more accursed thou, that still omitt'st it.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p:
Thou art going to Lord Timon's
feast?

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p: Ay, to see meat fill knaves and wine heat fools.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p: Fare thee well, fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
Thou art a fool to bid me farewell
twice.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p: Why, Apemantus?

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
Shouldst have kept one to thyself,
for I mean
to give thee none.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p: Hang thyself!

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
No, I will do nothing at thy bidding:
make thy requests to thy friend.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p:
Away, unpeaceable dog,
or I'll
spurn thee hence!

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
I will fly, like a dog, the heels o'
the ass. [Exit.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.l:
He's opposite to humanity.
Come, shall we in,
And taste Lord Timon's bounty? he outgoes
The very heart of kindness.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.l: He pours it out; Plutus, the god of gold,
Is but his steward: no meed, but he repays
Sevenfold above itself; no gift to him,
But breeds the giver a return exceeding
All use of quittance.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.l: The noblest mind he carries
That ever govern'd man.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.l: Long may he live in fortunes! Shall we in?

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.l: I'll keep you company. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II
div.stage: A banqueting-room in Timon's house.

Hautboys playing loud music.
A great banquet served in; FLAVIUS and others attending;

then enter LORD TIMON, ALCIBIADES,
Lords, Senators, and VENTIDIUS. Then comes, dropping after all, APEMANTUS,
discontentedly, like himself.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Most honour'd Timon,
It hath pleased the gods to remember my father's age,
And call him to long peace.
He is gone happy, and has left me rich:
Then, as in grateful virtue I am bound
To your free heart, I do return those talents,
Doubled with thanks and service, from whose help
I derived liberty.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: O, by no means,
Honest Ventidius; you mistake my love:
I gave it freely ever; and there's none
Can truly say he gives, if he receives:
If our betters play at that game, we must not dare
To imitate them; faults that are rich are fair.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: A noble spirit!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Nay, my lords, [They all stand ceremoniously looking on Timon.
Ceremony was but devised at first
To set a gloss on faint deeds, hollow welcomes,
Recanting goodness, sorry ere 'tis shown;
But where there is true friendship, there needs none.
Pray, sit; more welcome are ye to my fortunes
Than my fortunes to me. [They sit.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.l: My lord, we always have confess'd it.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.l: Ho, ho, confess'd it! hang'd it, have you not?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: O, Apemantus, you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.l: No;
You shall not make me welcome:
I come to have thee thrust me out of doors.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Fie, thou'rt a churl; ye 've got a humour there
sp.p:
Does not become a man; 'tis much to blame.
They say, my lords, 'ira furor brevis est;'
but
yond man is ever angry.
Go, let him have a
table by himself,
for he does neither affect
company,
nor is he fit for 't, indeed.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
Let me stay at thine apperil, Timon:
I come to observe; I give thee warning on 't.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
I take no heed of thee; thou 'rt an
Athenian,
therefore welcome: I myself would
have no power;
prithee, let my meat make
thee silent.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
I scorn thy meat; 'twould choke
me, for I
should ne'er flatter thee. O you gods,
what a number
of men eat Timon, and he sees
'em not! It grieves me
to see so many dip their
meat in one man's blood; and
all the madness
is, he cheers them up too.
sp.l: I wonder men dare trust themselves with men:
Methinks they should invite them without knives;
Good for their meat, and safer for their lives.
sp.p:
There's much example for 't; the fellow that 
sits next him 
now, parts bread with him, 
pledges the breath of him in 
a divided draught, 
is the readiest man to kill him: 't
              has 
been 
proved. If I were a huge man, I should fear
                
to 
drink at meals;
sp.l:
Lest they should spy my windpipe's
dangerous notes:

Great men should drink with harness
on their throats.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: My lord, in heart; and let the health go round.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.l: Let it flow this way, my good lord.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
Flow this way! A brave fellow he
keeps his
tides well. Those healths will make
thee and thy state
look ill, Timon.
Here's that
which is too weak to be a sinner,
honest water,
which ne'er left man i' the mire:
sp.l: This and my food are equals; there's no odds;

Feasts are too proud to give thanks to the gods,
Apemantus' grace.
Immortal gods, I crave no pelf;
I pray for no man but myself:
Grant I may never prove so fond,
To trust man on his oath or bond;
Or a harlot, for her weeping;
Or a dog, that seems a-sleeping;
Or my friends, if I should need 'em.
Amen. So fall to't:
Rich men sin, and I eat root. [Eats and drinks.
Much good dich thy good heart, Apemantus!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
Captain
Alcibiades, your heart's in
the field now.

sp.speaker: Alcib.
sp.p:
My heart is ever at your service, my
lord.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
You had rather be at a breakfast of
enemies
than a dinner of friends.

sp.speaker: Alcib.
sp.p:
So they were bleeding-new, my lord,
there's no
meat like 'em: I could wish my
best friend at such a feast.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
Would all those flatterers were thine
enemies
then, that then thou mightst kill 'em
and bid me to 'em!

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p:
Might we but have that happiness,
my lord,
that you would once use our
hearts, whereby we might
express some part of
our zeals, we should think ourselves
for ever
perfect.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
O, no doubt, my good friends, but the
gods
themselves have provided that I shall have
much help
from you: how had you been my
friends else? why
have you that charitable title
from thousands, did not
you chiefly belong to
my heart? I have told more of
you to myself
than you can with modesty speak in
your own
behalf; and thus far I confirm you. O
you
gods, think I, what need we have any friends,
if
we should ne'er have need of 'em? they were
the most
needless creatures living, should we
ne'er have use for
'em, and would most resemble
sweet instruments
hung up in cases
that keep their sounds to themselves.
Why,
I have often wished myself poorer, that
I might
come nearer to you. We are born to do benefits:
and what better or properer can we call
our own
than the riches of our friends? O,
what a precious comfort
'tis, to have so many,
like brothers, commanding
one another's fortunes!
O joy, e'en made away ere't
can be
born! Mine eyes cannot hold out water, methinks:
to forget their faults, I drink to you.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.l: Thou weepest to make them drink, Timon.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.l: Joy had the like conception in our eyes
And at that instant like a babe sprung up.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.l: Ho, ho! I laugh to think that babe a bastard.

sp.speaker: Third Lord.
sp.l: I promise you, my lord, you moved me much.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.l:
Much!
[Tucket, within.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: What means that trump? Enter a Servant.
How now?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p:
Please you, my lord, there are certain
ladies
most desirous of admittance.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Ladies! what are their wills?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p:
There comes with them a forerunner,
my lord,
which bears that office, to signify
their pleasures.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
I pray, let them be admitted.
Enter CUPID.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: Hail to thee, worthy Timon, and to all

That of
his bounties taste! The five best senses

Acknowledge thee
their patron; and come freely

To gratulate thy plenteous
bosom:
th' ear,
Taste, touch and smell, pleased from thy table rise;
They only now come but to feast thine eyes.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: They're welcome all; let 'em have kind admittance:
Music, make their welcome! [Exit Cupid.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.l:
You see, my lord, how ample you 're beloved. Music. Re-enter CUPID, with a mask of
Ladies as Amazons, with lutes in their
hands, dancing and playing.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.l:
Hoy-day,
what a sweep of vanity comes this way!
They dance! they are mad women.
Like madness is the glory of this life,
As this pomp shows to a little oil and root.
We make ourselves fools, to disport ourselves;
And spend our flatteries, to drink those men
Upon whose age we void it up again,
With poisonous spite and envy.
Who lives that's not depraved or depraves?
Who dies, that bears not one spurn to their graves
Of their friends' gift?
I should fear those that dance before me now
Would one day stamp upon me: 't has been done;

Men shut their doors against a setting sun.
The Lords rise from table, with much adoring
of TIMON; and
to show their loves, each
singles out an Amazon, and all
dance, men
with women, a lofty strain or two to the
hautboys, and cease.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l:
You have done our pleasures
much grace, fair ladies,
Set a fair fashion on our entertainment,
Which was not half so beautiful and kind;
You have added worth unto 't and lustre,
And entertain'd me with mine own device;
I am to thank you for 't.

sp.speaker: First Lady.
sp.l: My lord, you take us even at the best.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
'Faith, for the worst is filthy; and
would not hold
taking, I doubt me.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Ladies, there is an idle banquet attends you:
Please you to dispose yourselves.

sp.speaker: All Ladies.
sp.l: Most thankfully, my lord. Exeunt Cupid and Ladies.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Flavius.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: My lord?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: The little casket bring me hither.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Yes, my lord. More jewels yet! [Aside.]
There is no crossing him in's humour;
Else I should tell him,--well, i' faith, I should,
When all's spent, he'ld be cross'd then, an he could.
'Tis pity bounty had not eyes behind
That man might ne'er be wretched for his mind. [Exit.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.l: Where be our men?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Here, my lord, in readiness.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.l: Our horses! Re-enter FLAVIUS, with the casket.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: O my friends,
I have one word to say to you: look you, my good lord,
I must entreat you, honour me so much
As to advance this jewel; accept it and wear it,
Kind my lord.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.l: I am so far already in your gifts,--

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l:
So are we all.
Enter a Servant.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: My lord, there are certain nobles of the senate
Newly alighted, and come to visit you.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: They are fairly welcome.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: I beseech your honour,

Vouchsafe me a word; it
does concern you near.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Near! why then, another time I'll hear thee:
I prithee, let's be provided to show the entertainment.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l:
I scarce know how.
Enter a second Servant.

sp.speaker: Sec. Serv.
sp.l: May it please your honour, Lord Lucius,
Out of his free love, hath presented to you
Four milk-white horses, trapp'd in silver.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I shall accept them fairly; let the presents

Be worthily entertain'd.
Enter a third Servant.
How now! what news?

sp.speaker: Third Serv.
sp.p:
Please you, my lord, that honourable
gentleman,
Lord Lucullus, entreats your
company to-morrow
to hunt with him, and has
sent your honour two brace
of greyhounds.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l:
I'll hunt with him;
and let them be received,
Not without fair reward.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: What will this come to?
He commands us to provide, and give great gifts,

And
all out of an empty coffer:
Nor will he know his purse, or yield me this,
To show him what a beggar his heart is,
Being of no power to make his wishes good:
His promises fly so beyond his state
That what he speaks is all in debt; he owes
For every word; he is so kind that he now
Pays interest for't; his land's put to their books.
Well, would I were gently put out of office
Before I were forced out!
Happier is he that has no friend to feed
Than such that do e'en enemies exceed.
I bleed inwardly for my lord. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: You do yourselves
Much wrong, you bate too much of your own merits:
Here, my lord, a trifle of our love.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.l: With more than common thanks I will receive it.

sp.speaker: Third Lord.
sp.l: O, he 's the very soul of bounty !

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: And now I remember, my lord, you gave

Good
words the other day of a bay courser

I rode on: it is yours,
because you liked it.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.l: O, I beseech you, pardon me my lord, in that.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l:
You may take my word, my lord; I know, no
man
Can justly praise but what he does affect:

I weigh
my friend's affection with mine own;

I'll tell you true.
I'll call to you.

sp.speaker: All Lords.
sp.l: O, none so welcome.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I take all and your several visitations
So kind to heart, 'tis not enough to give;
Methinks, I could deal kingdoms to my friends,
And ne'er be weary. Alcibiades,
Thou art a soldier, therefore seldom rich:
It comes in charity to thee: for all thy living
Is 'mongst the dead, and all the lands thou hast
Lie in a pitch'd field.

sp.speaker: Alcib.
sp.l: Ay, defiled land, my lord.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.l: We are so virtuously bound--

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: And so
Am I to you.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.l: So infinitely endear'd--

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: All to you. Lights, more lights!

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.l: The best of happiness,
Honour and fortunes, keep with you, Lord Timon!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Ready for his friends. [Exeunt all but Apemantus and Timon.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.l: What a coil's here!

Serving of becks and jutting-out
of bums!

I doubt whether their legs be
worth the sums

That are given for 'em.
Friendship's full of dregs:
Methinks, false hearts should never have sound legs.
Thus honest fools lay out their wealth on court'sies.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Now, Apemantus, if thou wert not sullen,
I would be good to thee.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
No, I'll nothing: for if I should be
bribed too,
there would be none left to rail
upon thee, and then thou
wouldst sin the faster.
Thou givest so long, Timon, I
fear me thou
wilt give away thyself in paper shortly:
what
need these feasts, pomps and vain-glories?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
Nay, an you begin to rail on society
once, I
am sworn not to give regard to you.
Farewell; and come
with better music. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.l: So:

Thou wilt not hear me now; thcu shalt
not then:
I'll lock thy heaven from thee.
O, that men's ears should be
To counsel deaf, but not to flattery! [Exit.

div.head: SCENE I
div.stage: A Senator's house.
Enter Senator, with papers in his hand.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: And late, five thousand: to Varro and to Isidore
He owes nine thousand; besides my former sum,
Which makes it five and twenty. Still in motion
Of raging waste? It cannot hold; it will not.
If I want gold, steal but a beggar's dog,
And give it Timon, why, the dog coins gold.
If I would sell my horse, and buy twenty more
Better than he, why, give my horse to Timon,
Ask nothing, give it him, it foals me, straight,
And able horses. No porter at his gate,
But rather one that smiles and still invites
All that pass by. It cannot hold; no reason
Can found his state in safety. Caphis, ho!

Caphis, I say!
Enter CAPHIS.

sp.speaker: Caph.
sp.l: Here, sir; what is your pleasure?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Get on your cloak, and haste you to Lord Timon;
Importune him for my moneys; be not ceased
With slight denial, nor then silenced when--
'Commend me to your master'--and the cap
Plays in the right hand, thus: but tell him,
My uses cry to me, I must serve my turn
Out of mine own; his days and times are past
And my reliances on his fracted dates
Have smit my credit: I love and honour him,
But must not break my back to heal his finger;
Immediate are my needs, and my relief
Must not be toss'd and turn'd to me in words,
But find supply immediate. Get you gone:
Put on a most importunate aspect,
A visage of demand! for, I do fear,
When every feather sucks in his own wing,
Lord Timon will be left a naked gull,
Which flashes now a phoenix. Get you gone.

sp.speaker: Caph.
sp.l: I go, sir.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l:
'I go, sir!'--
Take the bonds along with you,
And have the dates in compt.

sp.speaker: Caph.
sp.l: I will, sir.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Go. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II
div.stage: The same. A hall in Timon's house.
Enter FLAVIUS, with many bills in his hand.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: No care, no stop! so senseless of expense,
That he will neither know how to maintain it,
Nor cease his flow of riot: takes no account
How things go from him, nor resumes no care
Of what is to continue: never mind
Was to be so unwise, to be so kind.
What shall be done? he will not hear, till feel:
I must be round with him, now he comes from hunting.

Fie, fie, fie, fie!
Enter CAPHIS, and the Servants of ISIDORE and VARRO.

sp.speaker: Caph.
sp.l: Good even, Varro: what,
You come for money?

sp.speaker: Var. Serv.
sp.l: Is 't not your business too?

sp.speaker: Caph.
sp.l: It is: and yours too, Isidore?

sp.speaker: Isid. Serv.
sp.l: It is so.

sp.speaker: Caph.
sp.l: Would we were all discharged!

sp.speaker: Var. Serv.
sp.l: I fear it.

sp.speaker: Caph.
sp.l:
Here comes the lord.
Enter TIMON, ALCIBIADES, and Lords, &c.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: So soon as dinner's done, we'll forth again,
My Alcibiades. With me? what is your will?

sp.speaker: Caph.
sp.l: My lord, here is a note of certain dues.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Dues! Whence are you?

sp.speaker: Caph.
sp.l: Of Athens here, my lord.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Go to my steward.

sp.speaker: Caph.
sp.l: Please it your lordship, he hath put me off
To the succession of new days this month:
My master is awaked by great occasion
To call upon his own, and humbly prays you
That with your other noble parts you'll suit
In giving him his right.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Mine honest friend,
I prithee, but repair to me next morning.

sp.speaker: Caph.
sp.l: Nay, good my lord,--

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Contain thyself, good friend.

sp.speaker: Var. Serv.
sp.l: One Varro's servant, my good lord,--

sp.speaker: Isid. Serv.
sp.l: From Isidore;

He humbly prays your speedy
payment.

sp.speaker: Caph.
sp.l: If you did know, my lord, my master's wants--

sp.speaker: Var. Serv.
sp.l: 'Twas due on forfeiture, my lord, six weeks
And past.

sp.speaker: Isid. Serv.
sp.l: Your steward puts me off, my lord;

And I
am sent expressly to your lordship.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Give me breath.
I do beseech you, good my lords, keep on;

I'll wait upon you instantly. [Exeunt Alcibiades and Lords.
[To Flav.]
Come hither: pray you.
How goes the world, that I am thus encounter'd
With clamorous demands of date-broke bonds,
And the detention of long-since-due debts,
Against my honour?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Please you, gentlemen,
The time is unagreeable to this business:
Your importunacy cease till after dinner,
That I may make his lordship understand
Wherefore you are not paid.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Do so, my friends. See them well entertain'd. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l:
Pray, draw near. Exit.
Enter APEMANTUS and Fool.

sp.speaker: Caph.
sp.p:
Stay, stay, here comes the fool with
Apemantus:
let's ha' some sport with 'em.

sp.speaker: Var. Serv.
sp.p: Hang him, he'll abuse us.

sp.speaker: Isid. Serv.
sp.p: A plague upon him, dog!

sp.speaker: Var. Serv.
sp.p: How dost, fool?

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p: Dost dialogue with thy shadow?

sp.speaker: Var. Serv.
sp.p: I speak not to thee.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p: No, 'tis to thyself. [To the Fool]
Come away.

sp.speaker: Isid. Serv.
sp.p:
There's the fool hangs on your
back already.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p: No, thou stand'st single, thou 'rt not on him yet.

sp.speaker: Caph.
sp.p: Where's the fool now?

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
He last asked the question. Poor
rogues, and usurers' men! bawds between gold
and want!

sp.speaker: All Serv.
sp.p: What are we, Apemantus?

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p: Asses.

sp.speaker: All Serv.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
That you ask me what you are, and
do not know
yourselves. Speak to 'em, fool.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: How do you, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: All Serv.
sp.p:
Gramercies, good fool:
how does
your mistress?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p:
She's e'en setting on water to scald
such
chickens as you are. Would we could
see you at Corinth!

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
Good! gramercy.
Enter Page.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p:
Look you, here comes my mistress'
page.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Why, how now, captain!
what do you in this
wise company?
How dost thou, Apemantus?

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
Would I had a rod in my mouth,
that I might
answer thee profitably.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Prithee, Apemantus, read me the
superscription
of these letters: I know not
which is which.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p: Canst not read?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
There will little learning die then.
that day thou
art hanged. This is to Lord
Timon; this to Alcibiades. Go;
thou wast
born a bastard, and thou 't die a bawd.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Thou wast whelped a dog, and thou
shalt
famish a dog's death.
Answer not; I am
gone. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
E'en so thou outrunnest grace.
Fool,
I will go with you to Lord Timon's.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Will you leave me there?

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
If Timon stay at home.
You three
serve three usurers?

sp.speaker: All Serv.
sp.p: Ay; would they served us!

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
So would I,--
as good a trick as
ever hangman served thief.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Are you three usurers' men?

sp.speaker: All Serv.
sp.p: Ay, fool.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p:
I think no usurer but has a fool to
his servant:
my mistress is one, and I am her
fool. When men
come to borrow of your
masters, they approach sadly,
and go away
merry; but they enter my mistress' house
merrily, and go away sadly: the reason of
this?

sp.speaker: Var. Serv.
sp.p: I could render one.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
Do it then, that we may account
thee a whoremaster
and a knave; which notwithstanding,
thou shalt
be no less esteemed.

sp.speaker: Var. Serv.
sp.p: What is a whoremaster, fool?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p:
A fool in good clothes, and something
like
thee. 'Tis a spirit: sometime 't appears
like a lord; sometime
like a lawyer;
sometime like a philosopher, with
two stones
moe than's artificial one: he is very often
like
a knight; and, generally, in all shapes that
man goes
up and down in from fourscore to
thirteen, this spirit
walks in.

sp.speaker: Var. Serv.
sp.p: Thou art not altogether a fool.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p:
Nor thou altogether a wise man:
as
much foolery as I have, so much wit thou
lackest.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p:
That answer might have become
Apemantus.

sp.speaker: All Serv.
sp.p:
Aside, aside; here comes Lord
Timon.
Re-enter TIMON and FLAVIUS.

sp.speaker: Apem.
sp.p: Come with me, fool, come.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p:
I do not always follow lover, elder
brother
and woman; sometime the
philosopher. [Exeunt Apemantus and Fool.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l:
Pray you, walk near;
I'll speak with you anon. [Exeunt Servants.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: You make me marvel: wherefore ere this time
Had you not fully laid my state before me,
That I might so have rated my expense,
As I had leave of means?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: You would not hear me,
At many leisures I proposed.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Go to:
Perchance some single vantages you took,
When my indisposition put you back;
And that unaptness made your minister,
Thus to excuse yourself.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: O my good lord,
At many times I brought in my accounts,
Laid them before you; you would throw them off,
And say, you found them in mine honesty.
When, for some trifling present, you have bid me
Return so much, I have shook my head and wept;
Yea, 'gainst the authority of manners, pray'd you
To hold your hand more close: I did endure
Not seldom, nor no slight checks, when I have
Prompted you in the ebb of your estate
And your great flow of debts. My loved lord,
Though you hear now, too late--yet now's a time--
The greatest of your having lacks a half
To pay your present debts.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Let all my land be sold.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: 'Tis all engaged, some forfeited and gone;
And what remains will hardly stop the mouth
Of present dues: the future comes apace:
What shall defend the interim? and at length
How goes our reckoning?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: To Lacedaemon did my land extend.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: O my good lord, the world is but a word:
Were it all yours to give it in a breath,
How quickly were it gone!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: You tell me true.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: If you suspect my husbandry or falsehood,
Call me before the exactest auditors
And set me on the proof. So the gods bless me,
When all our offices have been oppress'd
With riotous feeders, when our vaults have wept
With drunken spilth of wine, when every room
Hath blazed with lights and bray'd with minstrelsy,
I have retired me to a wasteful cock,
And set mine eyes at flow.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Prithee, no more.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Heavens, have I said, the bounty of this lord!
How many prodigal bits have slaves and peasants
This night englutted! Who is not Timon's?
What heart, head, sword, force, means, but is Lord Timon's?
Great Timon, noble, worthy, royal Timon!
Ah, when the means are gone that buy this praise,
The breath is gone whereof this praise is made:
Feast-won, fast-lost; one cloud of winter showers,
These flies are couch'd.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Come, sermon me no further;
No villanous bounty yet hath pass'd my heart;
Unwisely, not ignobly, have I given.
Why dost thou weep? Canst thou the conscience lack,
To think I shall lack friends? Secure thy heart;
If I would broach the vessels of my love,
And try the argument of hearts by borrowing,
Men and men's fortunes could I frankly use
As I can bid thee speak.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Assurance bless your thoughts!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: And, in some sort, these wants of mine are crown'd,
That I account them blessings; for by these

Shall I try friends: you shall perceive
how you

Mistake my fortunes;
I am wealthy in my friends.

Within there! Flaminius! Servilius!
Enter FLAMINIUS, SERVILIUS, and other
Servants.

sp.speaker: Servants.
sp.l: My lord? my lord?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
I will dispatch you severally;
you to
Lord Lucius; to Lord Lucullus you: I hunted
with his honour to-day: you, to Sempronius:
commend me
to their loves, and, I am proud,
say, that my occasions
have found time to use
'em toward a supply of money: let
the request
be fifty talents.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: As you have said, my lord.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Lord Lucius and Lucullus? hum!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Go you, sir, to the senators--
Of whom, even to the state's best health, I have
Deserved this hearing--bid 'em send o' the instant
A thousand talents to me.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: I have been bold--
For that I knew it the most general way--
To them to use your signet and your name;
But they do shake their heads, and I am here
No richer in return.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Is 't true? can 't be?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: They answer, in a joint and corporate voice,
That now they are at fall, want treasure, cannot
Do what they would; are sorry--you are honourable,--
But yet they could have wish'd--they know not--
Something hath been amiss--a noble nature
May catch a wrench--would all were well-'tis pity;--
And so, intending other serious matters,
After distasteful looks end these hard factions,
With certain half-caps and cold-moving nods
They froze me into silence.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: You gods, reward them!
Prithee, man, look cheerly. These old fellows
Have their ingratitude in them hereditary:
Their blood is caked, 'tis cold, it seldom flows;
'Tis lack of kindly warmth they are not kind;
And nature, as it grows again toward earth,
Is fashion'd for the journey, dull and heavy. [To a Serv.]
Go to Ventidius. [To Flav.] Prithee, be not sad,
Thou art true and honest; ingeniously I speak,
No blame belongs to thee. [To Ser.]
Ventidius lately
Buried his father; by whose death he's stepp'd
Into a great estate: when he was poor,
Imprison'd and in scarcity of friends,
I clear'd him with five talents: greet him from me;
Bid him suppose some good necessity
Touches his friend, which craves to be remember'd
With those five talents [Exit Serv.]
. [To Flav.] That had, give't these fellows
To whom 'tis instant due. Ne'er speak, or think,
That Timon's fortunes 'mong his friends can sink.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: I would I could not think it: that thought is bounty's foe;
Being free itself, it thinks all others so. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I
div.stage: A room in Lucullus' house.
FLAMINIUS waiting.
Enter a Servant to him.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p:
I have told my lord of you; he is coming down
to you.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p:
I thank you, sir.
Enter LUCULLUS.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Here's my lord.

sp.speaker: Lucul.
sp.p:
One of Lord Timon's men?
a gift, I warrant.
Why, this hits right; I dreamt
of a silver basin and ewer
to-night. Flaminius,
honest Flaminius; you are very respectively
welcome, sir. Fill me some wine. [Exit Serv.]
And how
does that honourable, complete,
free-hearted gentleman
of Athens, thy
very bountiful good lord and
master?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: His health is well, sir.

sp.speaker: Lucul.
sp.p:
I am right glad that his health is
well, sir: and
what hast thou there under thy
cloak, pretty Flaminius?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p:
'Faith, nothing but an empty box,
sir; which, in
my lord's behalf, I come to entreat
your honour to supply;
who, having great
and instant occasion to use fifty
talents, hath
sent to your lordship to furnish him, nothing
doubting your presert assistance therein.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
La, la, la, la! 'nothing doubting,'
says he? Alas,
good lord! a noble gentleman
'tis, if he would not keep
so good a house.
Many a time and often I ha' dined with
him,
and told him on 't, and come again to supper
to him,
of purpose to have him spend less, and
yet he would embrace
no counsel, take no
warning by my coming. Every
man has his
fault, and honesty is his: I ha' told him on't,
but I could ne'er get him from't.
Re-enter Servant, with wine.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Please your lordship, here is the wine.

sp.speaker: Lucul.
sp.p:
Flaminius, I have noted thee always
wise.
Here's to thee.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Your lordship speaks your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Lucul.
sp.p:
I have observed thee always for a
towardly
prompt spirit--give thee thy due--and
one that knows
what belongs to reason; and
canst use the time well, if the
time use thee
well: good parts in thee. [To Serv.] Get
you gone, sirrah Exit Serv.
Draw nearer,
honest Flaminius. Thy lord's a bountiful
gentleman:
but thou art wise; and thou knowest
well
enough, although thou comest to me, that this
is no
time to lend money, especially upon bare
friendship,
without security. Here's three solidares
for thee: good
boy, wink at me, and say
thou sawest me not. Fare thee
well.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Is't possible the world should so much differ,
And we alive that lived? Fly, damned baseness,
To him that worships thee! [Throwing the money back.

sp.speaker: Lucul.
sp.p:
Ha! now I see thou art a fool, and
fit for thy
master. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: May these add to the number that may scald thee!
Let molten coin be thy damnation,
Thou disease of a friend, and not himself!
Has friendship such a faint and milky heart,
It turns in less than two nights? O you gods,
I feel my master's passion! this slave,
Unto his honour, has my lord's meat in him:
Why should it thrive and turn to nutriment,
When he is turn'd to poison?
O, may disease only work upon't!
And, when he's sick to death, let not that part of nature
Which my lord paid for, be of any power
To expel sickness, but prolong his hour! [Exit.

div.head: SCENE II
div.stage: A public place.
Enter Lucius, with three Strangers.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Who, the Lord Timon? he is my very
good friend,
and an honourable gentleman.

sp.speaker: First Stran.
sp.p:
We know him for no less,
though we are but strangers
to him. But I can
tell you one thing, my lord, and
which I hear
from common rumours: now Lord Timon's
happy hours are done and past, and his estate
shrinks
from him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Fie, no, do not believe it; he cannot
want
for money.

sp.speaker: Sec. Stran.
sp.p:
But believe you this, my lord,
that, not long ago,
one of his men was with the
Lord Lucullus to borrow so
many talents, nay,
urged extremely for 't and showed
what necessity
belonged to 't, and yet was denied.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Sec. Stran.
sp.p: I tell you, denied, my lord.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
What a strange case was that! now,
before the
gods, I am ashamed on't. Denied
that honourable man!
there was very little honour
showed in't. For my own
part, I must
needs confess, I have received some small
kindnesses
from him, as money, plate, jewels and
such-like
trifles, nothing comparing to his; yet,
had he mistook
him and sent to me, I should
ne'er have denied his
occasion so many talents.
Enter SERVILIUS.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
See, by good hap, yonder's my lord;
I have
sweat to see his honour. My honoured
lord,-- [To Lucius.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Servilius! you are kindly met, sir.
Fare thee well:
commend me to thy honourable
virtuous lord, my very
exquisite friend.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
May it please your honour, my lord
hath
sent--

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Ha! what has he sent? I am so much
endeared
to that lord; he's ever sending: how
shall I thank him,
thinkest thou? And what
has he sent now?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
Has only sent his present occasion
now, my
lord; requesting your lordship to supply
his instant use
with so many talents.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I know his lordship is but merry with me;
He cannot want fifty five hundred talents.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: But in the mean time he wants less, my lord.
If his occasion were not virtuous,
I should not urge it half so faithfully.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Dost thou speak seriously, Servillius?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Upon my soul, 'tis true, sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
What a wicked beast was I to disfurnish
myself
against such a good time, when I might
ha' shown myself
honourable! how unluckily
it happened, that I should
purchase the day
before for a little part, and undo a great
deal
of honour! Servilius, now, before the gods, I
am
not able to do,--the more beast, I say:--I
was sending to use
Lord Timon myself, these
gentlemen can witness; but
I would not, for
the wealth of Athens, I had done't now.
Commend
me bountifully to his good lordship;
and I
hope his honour will conceive the
fairest of me, because
I have no power to be
kind: and tell him this from me,
I count it
one of my greatest afflictions, say, that I cannot
pleasure such an honourable gentleman.
Good Servilius,
will you befriend me so far
as to use mine own
words to him?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes, sir, I shall.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I'll look you out a good turn, Servilius. [Exit Servilius.
sp.l: True, as you said, Simon is shrunk indeed;
And he that's once denied will hardly speed. [Exit.

sp.speaker: First Stran.
sp.l: Do you observe this, Hostilius?

sp.speaker: Sec. Stran.
sp.l: Ay, too well.

sp.speaker: First Stran.
sp.l:
Why, this is the world's soul;
and just of the same piece
Is every flatterer's spirit. Who can call him

His friend
that dips in the same dish? for, in

My knowing,
Timon has been this lord's father,
And kept his credit with his purse,
Supported his estate; nay, Timon's money
Has paid his men their wages: he ne'er drinks,
But Timon's silver treads upon his lip;
And yet--O, see the monstrousness of man
When he looks out in an ungrateful shape!--
He does deny him, in respect of his,
What charitable men afford to beggars.

sp.speaker: Third Stran.
sp.l: Religion groans at it.

sp.speaker: First Stran.
sp.l: For mine own part,
I never tasted Timon in my life,
Nor came any of his bounties over me,
To mark me for his friend; yet, I protest,
For his right noble mind, illustrious virtue
And honourable carriage,
Had his necessity made use of me,
I would have put my wealth into donation,
And the best half should have return'd to him,
So much I love his heart: but, I perceive,
Men must learn now with pity to dispense;
For policy sits above conscience. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III
div.stage: A room in Sempronius' house.

Enter SEMPRONIUS, and a Servant
of TIMON'S.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: Must he needs trouble me in't,--hum!
--'bove all others?
He might have tried Lord Lucius or Lucullus;
And now Ventidius is wealthy too,
Whom he redeem'd from prison: all these
Owe their estates unto him.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: My lord,
They have all been touch'd and found base metal, for
They have all denied him.

sp.speaker: Sem.
sp.l: How! have they denied him?
Has Ventidius and Lucullus denied him?
And does he send to me? Three? hum!
It shows but little love or judgement in him:
Must I be his last refuge? His friends, like physicians,
Thrive, give him over: must I take the cure upon me?
Has much disgraced me in't; I'm angry at him,
That might have known my place: I see no sense for't.
But his occasions might have woo'd me first;
For, in my conscience, I was the first man
That e'er received gift from him:
And does he think so backwardly of me now,
That I'll requite it last? No:
So it may prove an argument of laughter
To the rest, and 'mongst lords I be thought a fool.
I'ld rather than the worth of thrice the sum,
Had sent to me first, but for my mind's sake;
I 'd such a courage to do him good. But now return,
And with their faint reply this answer join;
Who bates mine honour shall not know my coin. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p:
Excellent! Your lordship's a goodly
villain. The
devil knew not what he did
when he made man politic;
he crossed himself
by't: and I cannot think but,
in the end,
the villanies of man will set him clear. How
fairly this lord strives to appear foul! takes
virtuous
copies to be wicked, like those that
under hot ardent
zeal would set whole realms
on fire:
sp.l:
Of such nature
is his politic love.
This was my lord's best hope; now all are fled,
Save only the gods: now his friends are dead,
Doors, that were ne'er acquainted with their wards
Many a bounteous year, must be employ'd
Now to guard sure their master.
And this is all a liberal course allows;
Who cannot keep his wealth must keep his house. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE IV
div.stage: The same. A hall in Timon's house.

Enter two Servants of VARRO, and the Servant of LUCIUS, meeting TITUS, HORTENSIUS, and other Servants of TIMON'S creditors,
waiting his coming out.

sp.speaker: First Var. Serv.
sp.l: Well met: good morrow, Titus and Hortensius.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: The like to you, kind Varro.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Lucius!
What, do we meet together?

sp.speaker: Luc. Serv.
sp.l: Ay, and I think

One business does command us all;
for mine
Is money.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l:
So is theirs and ours.
Enter PHILOTUS.

sp.speaker: Luc. Serv.
sp.l: And Sir Philotus too!

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Good day at once.

sp.speaker: Luc. Serv.
sp.l: Welcome, good brother.
What do you think the hour?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Labouring for nine.

sp.speaker: Luc. Serv.
sp.l: So much?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Is not my lord seen yet?

sp.speaker: Luc. Serv.
sp.l: Not yet.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I wonder on 't; he was wont to shine at seven.

sp.speaker: Luc. Serv.
sp.l: Ay, but the days are wax'd shorter with him:
You must consider that a prodigal course
Is like the sun's; but not, like his, recoverable.

I fear
'tis deepest winter in Lord Timon's purse;

That is, one
may reach deep enough, and yet
Find little.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I am of your fear for that.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: I'll show you how to observe a strange event.
Your lord sends now for money.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Most true, he does.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: And he wears jewels now of Timon's gift,
For which I wait for money.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: It is against my heart.

sp.speaker: Luc. Serv.
sp.l: Mark, how strange it shows,
Timon in this should pay more than he owes:
And e'en as if your lord should wear rich jewels,
And send for money for 'em.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l:
I'm weary of this charge,
the gods can witness:
I know my lord hath spent of Timon's wealth,
And now ingratitude makes it worse than stealth.

sp.speaker: First Var. Serv.
sp.l:
Yes, mine's three thousand crowns:
what's yours?

sp.speaker: Luc. Serv.
sp.l: Five thousand mine.

sp.speaker: First Var. Serv.
sp.l: 'Tis much deep: and it should seem by the sum,
Your master's confidence was above mine;

Else, surely, his had equall'd.
Enter FLAMINIUS.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: One of Lord Timon's men.

sp.speaker: Luc. Serv.
sp.p:
Flaminius! Sir, a word: pray,
is my lord ready
to come forth?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: No, indeed, he is not.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.p:
We attend his lordship; pray, signify
so much.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p:
I need not tell him that; he knows
you are too diligent. [Exit.
Enter FLAVIUS in a cloak, muffled.

sp.speaker: Luc. Serv.
sp.l: Ha! is not that his steward muffled so?
He goes away in a cloud: call him, call him.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.p: Do you hear, sir?

sp.speaker: Sec. Var. Serv.
sp.p: By your leave, sir,--

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: What do ye ask of me, my friend?

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: We wait for certain money here, sir.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Ay,
If money were as certain as your waiting,
'Twere sure enough.
Why then preferr'd you not your sums and bills,
When your false masters eat of my lord's meat?
Then they could smile and fawn upon his debts
And take down the interest into their gluttonous maws.
You do yourselves but wrong to stir me up;
Let me pass quietly:
Believe't, my lord and I have made an end;
I have no more to reckon, he to spend.

sp.speaker: Luc. Serv.
sp.l: Ay, but this answer will not serve.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: If 'twill not serve, 'tis not so base as you;
For you serve knaves. [Exit.

sp.speaker: First Var. Serv.
sp.p:
How! what does his cashiered
worship
mutter?

sp.speaker: Sec. Var. Serv.
sp.p:
No matter what; he's
poor, and that's revenge
enough. Who can
speak broader than he that
has no house to
put his head in? such may rail against
great
buildings.
Enter SERVILIUS.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.p:
O, here's Servilius; now we shall
know some
answer.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
If I might beseech you, gentlemen, to
repair
some other hour, I should derive much
from 't; for, take't
of my soul, my lord leans
wondrously to discontent:
his comfortable
temper has forsook him; he's much out
of
health, and keeps his chamber.

sp.speaker: Luc. Serv.
sp.l: Many do keep their chambers are not sick:
And, if it be so far beyond his health,
Methinks he should the sooner pay his debts,
And make a clear way to the gods.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Good gods!

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: We cannot take this for answer, sir.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l:
Servilius, help! My lord! my lord!
Enter TIMON, in a rage; FLAMINIUS
following.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: What, are my doors opposed against my passage?
Have I been ever free, and must my house
Be my retentive enemy, my gaol?
The place which I have feasted, does it now,
Like all mankind, show me an iron heart?

sp.speaker: Luc. Serv.
sp.p: Put it now, Titus.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.p: My lord, here is my bill.

sp.speaker: Luc. Serv.
sp.p: Here's mine.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: And mine, my lord.

sp.speaker: Both Var. Serv.
sp.p: And ours, my lord.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: All our bills.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
Knock me down with 'em: cleave me to the
girdle.

sp.speaker: Luc. Serv.
sp.p: Alas, my lord,--

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Cut my heart in sums.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.p: Mine, fifty talents.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Tell out my blood.

sp.speaker: Luc. Serv.
sp.p: Five thousand crowns, my lord.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
Five thousand drops pays that.
What yours?--and yours?

sp.speaker: First Var. Serv.
sp.p: My lord,--

sp.speaker: Sec. Var. Serv.
sp.p: My lord,--

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
Tear me, take me, and the gods fall upon you!
[Exit.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
'Faith, I perceive our masters may
throw their
caps at their money: these debts
may well be called desperate
ones, for a madman
owes 'em. [Exeunt.
Re-enter TIMON and FLAVIUS.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l:
They have e'en put my breath from me, the
slaves.
Creditors? devils!

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: My dear lord,--

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: What if it should be so?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: My lord,--

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I'll have it so. My steward!

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Here, my lord.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: So fitly? Go, bid all my friends again.
Lucius, Lucullus, and Sempronius:
All, sirrah, all:
I'll once more feast the rascals.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: O, my lord,

You only speak from your distracted
soul;
There is not so much left, to furnish out

A moderate
table.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l:
Be 't not in thy care;
go,
I charge thee, invite them all: let in the tide
Of knaves once more; my cook and I'll provide. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE V
div.stage:
The same. The senate-house
The Senate sitting.

sp.speaker: First Sen.
sp.l:
My lord, you have my voice to it;
the fault's

Bloody;
'tis necessary he should die:
Nothing emboldens sin so much as mercy.

sp.speaker: Sec. Sen.
sp.l: Most true; the law shall bruise him. Enter ALCIBIADES, with Attendants.

sp.speaker: Alcib.
sp.l: Honour, health, and compassion to the senate!

sp.speaker: First Sen.
sp.l: Now, captain?

sp.speaker: Alcib.
sp.l: I am an humble suitor to your virtues;
For pity is the virtue of the law,
And none but tyrants use it cruelly.
It pleases time and fortune to lie heavy
Upon a friend of mine, who, in hot blood,
Hath stepp'd into the law, which is past depth
To those that, without heed, do plunge into 't.
He is a man, setting his fate aside,
Of comely virtues:
Nor did he soil the fact with cowardice--
An honour in him which buys out his fault--
But with a noble fury and fair spirit,
Seeing his reputation touch'd to death,
He did oppose his foe:
And with such sober and unnoted passion
He did behave his anger, ere 'twas spent,
As if he had but proved an argument.

sp.speaker: First Sen.
sp.l: You undergo too strict a paradox,
Striving to make an ugly deed look fair:
Your words have took such pains as if they labour'd
To bring manslaughter into form and set quarrelling
Upon the head of valour; which indeed
Is valour misbegot and came into the world
When sects and factions were newly born:
He's truly valiant that can wisely suffer
The worst that man can breathe, and make his wrongs
His outsides, to wear them like his raiment, carelessly,
And ne'er prefer his injuries to his heart,
To bring it into danger.
If wrongs be evils and enforce us kill,
What folly 'tis to hazard life for ill!

sp.speaker: Alcib.
sp.l: My lord,--

sp.speaker: First Sen.
sp.l: You cannot make gross sins look clear:
To revenge is no valour, but to bear.

sp.speaker: Alcib.
sp.l: My lords, then, under favour, pardon me,
If I speak like a captain.
Why do fond men expose themselves to battle,
And not endure all threats? sleep upon 't,
And let the foes quietly cut their throats,
Without repugnancy? If there be
Such valour in the bearing, what make we
Abroad? why then, women are more valiant
That stay at home, if bearing carry it,
And the ass more captain than the lion, the felon
Loaden with irons wiser than the judge,
If wisdom be in suffering. O my lords,
As you are great, be pitifully good:
Who cannot condemn rashness in cold blood?
To kill, I grant, is sin's extremest gust;
But, in defence. by mercy, 'tis most just.
To be in anger is impiety;
But who is man that is not angry?
Weigh but the crime with this.

sp.speaker: Sec. Sen.
sp.l: You breathe in vain.

sp.speaker: Alcib.
sp.l:
In vain!
his service done
At Lacedaemon and Byzantium.
Were a sufficient briber for his life.

sp.speaker: First Sen.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Alcib.
sp.l: I say, my lords, he has done fair service,
And slain in fight many of our enemies:
How full of valour did he bear himself
In the last conflict, and made plenteous wounds!

sp.speaker: Sec. Sen.
sp.l: He has made too much plenty with 'em;
He's a sworn rioter: he has a sin that often
Drowns him, and takes his valour prisoner:
If there were no foes, that were enough
To overcome him: in that beastly fury
He has been known to commit outrages,
And cherish factions: 'tis inferr'd to us,
His days are foul and his drink dangerous.

sp.speaker: First Sen.
sp.l: He dies.

sp.speaker: Alcib.
sp.l: Hard fate! he might have died in war.
My lords, if not for any parts in him--
Though his right arm might purchase his own time
And be in debt to none--yet, more to move you,
Take my deserts to his, and join 'em both:
And, for I know your reverend ages love

Security,
I'll pawn my victories, all

My honours to you,
upon his good returns.
If by this crime he owes the law his life,
Why, let the war receive 't in valiant gore;
For law is strict, and war is nothing more.

sp.speaker: First Sen.
sp.l: We are for law: he dies; urge it no more,
On height of our displeasure: friend or brother,
He forfeits his own blood that spills another.

sp.speaker: Alcib.
sp.l:
Must it be so? it must not be.
My lords,
I do beseech you, know me.

sp.speaker: Sec. Sen.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Alcib.
sp.l: Call me to your remembrances.

sp.speaker: Third Sen.
sp.l: What!

sp.speaker: Alcib.
sp.l: I cannot think but your age has forgot me;
It could not else be, I should prove so base,
To sue, and be denied such common grace:
My wounds ache at you.

sp.speaker: First Sen.
sp.l: Do you dare our anger?
'Tis in few words, but spacious in effect;
We banish thee for ever.

sp.speaker: Alcib.
sp.l: Banish me!
Banish your dotage; banish usury,
That makes the senate ugly.

sp.speaker: First Sen.
sp.l: If, after two days' shine, Athens contain thee,

Attend our weighing judgement.
And, not to swell our spirit,
He shall be executed presently. [Exeunt Senators.

sp.speaker: Alcib.
sp.l:
Now the gods keep you old enough;
that you may live
Only in bone, that none may look on you!
I'm worse than mad: I have kept back their foes,
While they have told their money and let out
Their coin upon large interest, I myself
Rich only in large hurts. All those for this?
Is this the balsam that the usuring senate
Pours into captains' wounds? Banishment!
It comes not ill; I hate not to be banish'd;
It is a cause worthy my spleen and fury,
That I may strike at Athens. I'll cheer up
My discontented troops, and lay for hearts.
'Tis honour with most lands to be at odds;
Soldiers should brook as little wrongs as gods. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE VI
div.stage:
The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.
Music. Tables set out: Servants attending.

Enter divers Lords, Senators and others, at
several doors.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p:
The good time of day to you,
sir.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p:
I also wish it to you. I think
this honourable lord
did but try us this other
day.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p:
Upon that were my thoughts
tiring, when we encountered:
I hope it is not
so low with him as he made it
seem in the
trial of his several friends.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p:
It should not be, by the persuasion
of his new
feasting.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p:
I should think so: he hath sent
me an earnest inviting,
which many my near
occasions did urge me to
put off; but he hath
conjured me beyond them, and I
must needs
appear.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p:
In like manner was I in debt to
my importunate business,
but he would not
hear my excuse. I am sorry,
when he sent to
borrow of me, that my provision was
out.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p:
I am sick of that grief, too, as
I understand how all
things go.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p:
Every man here's so. What
would he have borrowed
of you?

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p: A thousand pieces.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p: A thousand pieces!

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p: What of you?

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p:
He sent to me, sir,--Here he
comes.
Enter TIMON and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Tim.
First Lord.
sp.p:
Ever at the best, hearing well
of your lordship.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p:
The swallow follows not summer
more willing
than we your lordship.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
Nor more willingly leaves
Winter; such summer-birds
are men. Gentlemen,
our dinner will not recompense
this long
stay: feast your ears with the music
awhile, if
they will fare so harshly o' the trumpet's
sound; we shall to't presently.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p:
I hope it remains not unkindly
with your lordship
that I returned you an
empty messenger.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: O, sir, let it not trouble you.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p: My noble lord,--

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ah, my good friend, what cheer?

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p:
My most honourable lord, I
am e'en sick of shame,
that, when your lordship
this other day sent to me, I was
so unfortunate
a beggar.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Think not on't, sir.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p:
If you had sent but two hours
before,--

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
Let it not cumber your better remembrance.
[The banquet brought in.]
Come,
bring in all together.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p: All covered dishes!

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p: Royal cheer, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Third Lord.
sp.p:
Doubt not that, if money and
the season can yield it.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p: How do you? What's the news?

sp.speaker: Third Lord.
sp.p:
Alcibiades is banished: hear
you of it?

sp.speaker: First and Sec. Lord.
sp.p: Alcibiades banished!

sp.speaker: Third Lord.
sp.p: 'Tis so, be sure of it.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p: How! how!

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p: I pray you, upon what?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
My worthy friends, will you draw
near?

sp.speaker: Third Lord.
sp.p:
I'll tell you more anon.
Here's a noble feast toward.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p: This is the old man still.

sp.speaker: Third Lord.
sp.p: Will 't hold? will't hold?

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p:
It does: but time will--and
so--

sp.speaker: Third Lord.
sp.p: I do conceive.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
Each man to his stool, with that spur
as he
would to the lip of his mistress: your
diet shall be in all
places alike. Make not a
city feast of it, to let the meat
cool ere we can
agree upon the first place: sit, sit.
The gods
require our thanks.
You great benefactors, sprinkle our society
with thankfulness.
For your own gifts, make
yourselves praised: but
reserve still to give,
lest your deities be despised. Lend to each
man enough, that one need not lend to another;
for, were your
godheads to borrow of
men, men would forsake the gods. Make
the
meat be beloved more than the man that gives
it. Let
no assembly of twenty be without a
score of villains: if there
sit twelve women at
the table, let a dozen of them be--as they
are.
The rest of your fees, O gods--the senators
of Athens,
together with the common lag of
people--what is amiss in
them, you gods,
make suitable for destruction. For these my
present friends, as they are to me nothing, so
in nothing bless
them, and to nothing are they
welcome.
Uncover, dogs, and lap. The dishes are uncovered and seem to be full of warm water.

sp.speaker: Some speak.
sp.l: What does his lordship mean?

sp.speaker: Some other.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: May you a better feast never behold,
You knot of mouth-friends! smoke and lukewarm water
Is your perfection. This is Timon's last;
Who, stuck and spangled with your flatteries,
Washes it off, and sprinkles in your faces
Your reeking villany. Throwing the water in their faces.
Live loathed and long,
Most smiling, smooth, detested parasites,
Courteous destroyers, affable wolves, meek bears,
You fools of fortune, trencher-friends, time's flies,
Cap and knee slaves, vapours, and minutejacks!
Of man and beast the infinite malady
Crust you quite o'er! What, dost thou go?
Soft! take thy physic first--thou too--and thou;--

Stay, I will lend thee money, borrow none. [Throws the dishes at them, and drives
them out.
What, all in motion? Henceforth be no feast,
Whereat a villain's not a welcome guest.
Burn, house! sink, Athens! henceforth hated be

Of Timon man and all humanity! Exit.
Re-enter the Lords, Senators, &c.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p: How now, my lords!

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p:
Know you the quality of Lord
Timon's fury?

sp.speaker: Third Lord.
sp.p: Push! did you see my cap?

sp.speaker: Fourth Lord.
sp.p: I have lost my gown.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p:
He's but a mad lord, and
nought but humour sways
him. He gave me
a jewel th' other day, and now he has
beat
it out of my hat:
did you see my jewel?

sp.speaker: Third Lord.
sp.p: Did you see my cap?

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p: Here't is.

sp.speaker: Fourth Lord.
sp.p: Here lies my gown.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p: Let's make no stay.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p: Lord Timon's mad.

sp.speaker: Third Lord.
sp.p: I feel 't upon my bones.

sp.speaker: Fourth Lord.
sp.p:
One day he gives us diamonds, next day stones.
[Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I
div.stage: Without the walls of Athens.
Enter TIMON.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Let me look back upon thee. O thou wall,
That girdlest in those wolves, dive in the earth,
And fence not Athens! Matrons, turn incontinent!
Obedience fail in children! slaves and fools,
Pluck the grave wrinkled senate from the bench,
And minister in their steads! to general filths
Convert o' the instant, green virginity,
Do't in your parents' eyes! bankrupts, hold fast;
Rather than render back, out with your knives,
And cut your trusters' throats! bound servants, steal!
Large-handed robbers your grave masters are,
And pill by law. Maid, to thy master's bed;
Thy mistress is o' the brothel! Son of sixteen,
Pluck the lined crutch from thy old limping sire,
With it beat out his brains! Piety, and fear,
Religion to the gods, peace, justice, truth,
Domestic awe, night-rest, and neighbourhood,
Instruction, manners, mysteries, and trades,
Degrees, observances, customs, and laws,
Decline to your confounding contraries.
And let confusion live! Plagues, incident to men,
Your potent and infectious fevers heap
On Athens, ripe for stroke! Thou cold sciatica,
Cripple our senators, that their limbs may halt
As lamely as their manners! Lust and liberty
Creep in the minds and marrows of our youth,
That 'gainst the stream of virtue they may strive,
And drown themselves in riot! Itches, blains,
Sow all the Athenian bosoms; and their crop
Be general leprosy! Breath infect breath,
That their society, as their friendship, may
Be merely poison! Nothing I'll bear from thee,
But nakedness, thou detestable town!
Take thou that too, with multiplying bans
Timon will to the woods; where he shall find
The unkindest beast more kinder than mankind.
The gods confound--hear me, you good gods all--
The Athenians both within and out that wall!
And grant, as Timon grows, his hate may grow
To the whole race of mankind, high and low!
Amen. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE II
div.stage: Athens. A room in Timon's house.
Enter FLAVIUS, with two or three Servants.

sp.speaker: First Serv.
sp.l: Hear you, master steward, where's our master?
Are we undone? cast off? nothing remaining?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Alack, my fellows, what shall I say to you?
Let me be recorded by the righteous gods,
I am as poor as you.

sp.speaker: First Serv.
sp.l: Such a house broke!
So noble a master fall'n! All gone! and not
One friend to take his fortune by the arm,
And go along with him!

sp.speaker: Sec. Serv.
sp.l: As we do turn our backs
From our companion thrown into his grave,
So his familiars to his buried fortunes
Slink all away, leave their false vows with him,
Like empty purses pick'd; and his poor self,
A dedicated beggar to the air,
With his disease of all-shunn'd poverty,

Walks, like contempt, alone. More of our fellows.
Enter other Servants.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: All broken implements of a ruin'd house.

sp.speaker: Third Serv.
sp.l: Yet do our hearts wear Timon's livery;
That see I by our faces; we are fellows still,
Serving alike in sorrow: leak'd is our bark,
And we, poor mates, stand on the dying deck,
Hearing the surges threat: we must all part
Into this sea of air.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Good fellows all,
The latest of my wealth I'll share amongst you.
Wherever we shall meet, for Timon's sake,
Let's yet be fellows; let's shake our heads, and say,
As 'twere a knell unto our master's fortunes,
'We have seen better days.' Let each take some;
Nay, put out all your hands. Not one word more:

Thus we part rich in sorrow, parting poor.
Servants embrace, and part several ways.
O, the fierce wretchedness that glory brings us!
Who would not wish to be from wealth exempt,
Since riches point to misery and contempt?
Who would be so mock'd with glory? or to live
But in a dream of friendship?
To have his pomp and all what state compounds
But only painted, like his varnish'd friends?
Poor honest lord, brought low by his own heart,
Undone by goodness! Strange, unusual blood,
When man's worst sin is, he does too much good!
Who, then, dares to be half so kind again?
For bounty, that makes gods, does still mar men,
My dearest lord, bless'd, to be most accursed,
Rich, only to be wretched, thy great fortunes
Are made thy chief afflictions. Alas, kind lord!
He's flung in rage from this ingrateful seat

Of monstrous friends,
nor has he with him to

Supply his life,
or that which can command it.
I'll follow and inquire him out:
I'll ever serve his mind with my best will;
Whilst I have gold, I'll be his steward still. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE III
div.stage: Woods and cave, near the sea-shore.
Enter TIMON, from the cave.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: O blessed breeding sun, draw from the earth
Rotten humidity; below thy sister's orb
Infect the air! Twinn'd brothers of one womb,
Whose procreation, residence, and birth,
Scarce is dividant, touch them with several fortunes;
The greater scorns the lesser: not nature,
To whom all sores lay siege, can bear great fortunes;
But thy contempt of nature.
Raise me this beggar, and deny't that lord;
The senator shall bear contempt hereditary,
The beggar native honour.
It is the pasture lards the rother's sides,
The want that makes him lean. Who dares, who dares,
In purity of manhood stand upright,
And say 'This man's a flatterer'? if one be,
So are they all; for every grise of fortune
Is smooth'd by that below: the learned pate
Ducks to the golden fool: all is oblique;
There's nothing level in our cursed natures,
But direct villany. Therefore, be abhorr'd
All feasts, societies, and throngs of men!
His semblable, yea, himself, Timon disdains:
Destruction fang mankind! Earth, yield me roots! [Digging.
Who seeks for better of thee, sauce his palate
With thy most operant poison! What is here?

Gold? yellow, glittering, precious gold?
No, gods,

I am no idle votarist:
roots, you clear heavens

Thus much of this will make
black white, foul fair,

Wrong right,
base noble, old young, coward valiant.
Ha, you gods! why this? what this, you gods? Why, this
Will lug your priests and servants from your sides,
Pluck stout men's pillows from below their heads:
This yellow slave
Will knit and break religions, bless the accursed,
Make the hoar leprosy adored, place thieves
And give them title, knee and approbation
With senators on the bench: this is it
That makes the wappen'd widow wed again;
She, whom the spital-house and ulcerous sores
Would cast the gorge at, this embalms and spices
To the April day again. Come, damned earth,
Thou common whore of mankind, that put'st odds
Among the rout of nations, I will make thee
Do thy right nature. [March afar off.]
Ha! a drum? Thou'rt quick,
But yet I'll bury thee: thou 'lt go, strong thief,
When gouty keepers of thee cannot stand.

Nay, stay thou out for earnest. [Keeping some gold.
Enter ALCIBIADES, with drum and fife, in
warlike manner;
PHRYNIA and TIMANDRA.

sp.speaker: Alcib.
sp.l: What art thou there? speak.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: A beast, as thou art. The canker gnaw thy heart,
For showing me again the eyes of man!

sp.speaker: Alcib.
sp.l: What is thy name? Is man so hateful to thee,
That art thyself a man?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I am Misanthropos, and hate mankind.
For thy part, I do wish thou wert a dog,
That I might love thee something.

sp.speaker: Alcib.
sp.l: I know thee well;
But in thy fortunes am unlearn'd and strange.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I know thee too; and more than that I know thee,
I desire not to know. Follow thy drum;
With man's blood paint the ground, gules, gules:
Religious canons, civil laws are cruel;
Then what should war be? This fell whore of thine
Hath in her more destruction than thy sword,
For all her cherubin look.

sp.speaker: Phr.
sp.l: Thy lips rot off!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I will not kiss thee; then the rot returns
To thine own lips again.

sp.speaker: Alcib.
sp.l: How came the noble Timon to this change?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: As the moon does, by wanting light to give:
But then renew I could not, like the moon;
There were no suns to borrow of.

sp.speaker: Alcib.
sp.l: Noble Timon,
What friendship may I do thee?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: None, but to
Maintain my opinion.

sp.speaker: Alcib.
sp.l: What is it, Timon?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
Promise me friendship, but perform
none:
if thou wilt not promise, the gods plague
thee, for thou
